ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained knowledge about digital memorialization processes and insights as to how or why to critique them in relation to their effectiveness/respectfulness with the victims.
I learned how to apply anthropological and political perspectives to thinking about memory, especially as it relates to mass atrocities. I also gained writing and discussion skills.
I learned a lot about analyzing literature and about society and politics.
very good, applicable critical analysis skills
I have learned valuable information regarding the way in which mass attrocities are memorialized, as well as gained some insight into the respectful ways to memorialize such attrocities.

I learned a lot about the different ways mass atrocities are memorialized, including the different types of media used. It was really a great introduction into an entirely new field of learning and it encouraged me to explore other avenues for potential careers.
I learned a ton about various perspectives on different issues that relate to how to present and preserve certain perspectives throughout history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Having a presentation every class made me less engaged with the readings, I would have a discussion leader who only presents questions and reflections as opposed to summaries.

Strengths: I really enjoyed the readings and discussion topics we had, and loved talking to Prof. Simon, Prof. Zucker and classmates about these important issues. I also liked listening to the guest speakers and student presentations as well. 

Weaknesses: None that I can think of!

I think the strengths were the topics that we discussed and the weaknesses were that sometimes the topics were redundant and we could have maybe covered more ground. I also wish the students had a bit more say in what was discussed.
great seminar style discussion setting, well moderated, lots of student involvement
This course was extremely collaberative and provided valuable insight into important social issues.

The readings and conversations were interesting and useful. The field trip was a great additional component and the workload was manageable but still allowed me to learn a lot. I have no weaknesses to share - everything was great.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! I think the topics covered in this course are extremely important nowadays and they dont gain enough attention. If youre interested in history, memory, art, or digital processes, Id recommend you take this course, you wont regret it,

I would definitely recommend this class to another student! It strengthened my interest in learning about mass atrocities, and really taught me new perspectives on how to think about political issues. I would definitely urge any student taking this class to engage with all the readings and go to office hours to get the most out of it!
I would because I think it was really interesting and I enjoyed the environment
Yes
yes
Yes!
I definitely recommend for anyone who is interested in history, genocide studies, media studies, or ethics. It's a great intro to all of those subjects.
